titleStmt.title: M111, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession]. Typescript fragment, unsigned and undated. 4 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M111, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: Anonymity was a great possession]. Typescript fragment, unsigned and undated. 4 fols.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early plays writing a general nature. t (It) gave us the ballds (ballads); it gave us the somgs (songs). It allowed us to know nothing of the mans name. had great privileges. He is not responsible. He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can repeat. He can say what everyone feels. No one asks that he shall stamp his own name on his work. He keeps at a distance from the present moment. Anon the lyric writer repeat (repeats) over and
ove (over) again that flowers fade; that death is the end. He is never tired of clebrating (celebrating) red roses and the white
bresast (breast) of his mistress. The anonymous dxmxmxmxmxmx playwright has like the singer this namless (nameless) vitality. something drawn from the crowd in the penny seats. and not yet dead in ouslves (ourselves). For we too have become aninymous (anonymous), and forget something that we have learnt, in reading the plays that no one troubled to set a name to.

Later when the audience becomes critical, when the emotion in the audience becomes self oncsious (conscious), when the country squire can say without quoting what is in his mind, we lose this general quality to gain--- everything it seemes (seems). For until the shut the thea (theatre) the curayin (curtain) rises incesaantly (incessantly). It goes on rising until finally it rises on the . But by then the stage has become too small for the play. It has outgrown the uncovered theatre where eh (the) sun beats and the rain pours. And the reader is born. He acts the play in the theatre of his own brain. Perhaps after centuries the play is born again,

revealed, is often a supended (suspended) derelict irrelevant beauty. There is no sequence. It does not connect; axxxx the rxmxmxmxmxf the parts are u sevred (severed), and something runs to waste. For the anonuymous playwright is irrepsonsible (irresponsible). He flouts trith (truth) at the bidding of the audience. he cares ony (only) for the plot. We are left in the end without an end. The emotion is wasted.

But gradually the audience is mastered by the playwrgiht (playwright). The mist withdraws. So many darmatists (dramatists) are explroing (exploring) tunnels that lead at last to some common disocvery (discovery). So many private people are pressing their weight of
eunexpressed (unexpressed) emotion upon the writers consciouness (consciousness). Country squires are earning (learning) to speak what they feel without quoting Spenser. The curtain rises on play afte (after) play. Each time it rises upon a more detached, a more matured drama. The indivisual (individual) on the stage becomes more and more
diife entiated (differentiated); and the whole group is more closely
rleated (related) and less at the mercy of the lp plot. The curtain rises upon Hxmxmmxmx ; and ; upon and and upon . Finally it rises upon the Tempest. But the play has outgrown the uncovered theatre where the s n (sun) beats and the rain pours. That thetare (theatre) must be replaced by the
thestre (theatre) of the brain. The playwright is replaced by the man who writes a book. The audience is replaced by the reader. Anon is dead.

The audience at the Elizabetahn (Elizabethan) play was not an audiejce () of readers. They had to draw int (in) the play through their ears, through their eyes They could not deepen the impression and renew it at a table in a private room. This perhaps explains the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism; and the general nature of what criticism there is. Both and deal with the general rules of poetry; not with the particuar (particular) play or poem. The lack of a book of the words accounts too for the long pause, between death and the eighteenth century, whe (when) the plays of Shakepere (Shakespeare) even hang suspended, unrea ised (unrealised). They had to wait until the printed book was in many hands before they received the life that the reader co fers (confers) Much that was lost in the playhouse was disocvered (discovered) in the private room. But mu h (much) was lost for ever when the playhouse shut. Txmxmmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxm We have lost the sound of the spoken word; all that the sight of the actors bodies suggests to the mind through the eye. We have lost the sense of being part of the audience. We miss a th usnd (thousand) suggestions that the dramatist conveyed by the inflection of voice, by gesture, by the placing of the actors bodies. This can still be proved by comparing our impression
aft (after) seeing the play acted with our impression after reading the play alone. But as the actor ipmports (imports) much that is of his own day, and foreing ([foreign?]) to the past, so that there is t still something in every Elizabethan play sunk beyond recall.

Presumably the earlier plays, in which the playwright and the audience were mxxxx in closer cooperation, are the more damaged by reading them. The reader instinctivly (instinctively) tries to be there in person. He tries to supply the trumpets and the flags; the citizens and the apprentices. He nourishes the inadeuate (inadequate) emotion with a dip into , with a dip into . He labours to supply the sunk part of the play. He is perpetaully (perpetually) rebuffed. He is apt to become not a reader but a student; a crafeul (careful) collector of old scattered bones. At some point however in Elizabethan drama the readerr is born. When the dramatist beceomes (becomes) consi of the play as a work of art; when he is able to unite the play by something in himself--his personality, his conception-- it is then that, he brings the reader into beig (being)

We can be sure then that the reader has been in existence for round about four hundred years. But his life history is an obscure one. At some point his ear must have lost i s (its) acutness (acuteness); then his eyees (eyes) became dulled. Later he became more conscious of the suggestions and echoes in words. He imported much into the w itten (written) word that was unintended xxxxxxx by the writer. A word given in its Elizabethan spelling brings in suggestions that give it almost another meaning. The words suggest other manners, other clothes. They accent the contrast between one society and another. And as the habit of reading becomes universal, many varities (varieties) of reader are created. There are the
s ecialised (specialised) readers whose power of darwing (drawing) out the
